title: Is reading Copleston's 'A History of Philosophy' the best approach to build a bird’s-eye view of western philosophy? - Quora

response.answer_text: One question is: how high-flying a bird do you want to be? If you have the interest, the energy, and the patience to read all 9 volumes of Copleston, then I’d say, go for it! I’ve read about 4 volumes of the series, and I loved it. I read slowly, taking notes. If you read all 9 volumes with reasonable care, you will have a very good grounding in Western philosophy, I would say. You’d be a fairly low-flying bird, seeing a lot of detail. I think there are certain advantages to reading a history rather than just reading one particular philosopher. While Plato, for example, was a great philosopher, perhaps the greatest, he is still only one among many, and there are great thinkers who do not share his viewpoint. A good historian, which I think Copleston is, is aware of this and is able to set out the various points of view, while also keeping his own views in perspective. You can’t do a major history such as Copleston’s without loving philosophy—all of it. I think reading Copleston’s history is a wonderful project. I haven’t finished it myself yet, but I would love to do so. And even if you only get part way through volume 1, hey, you’re still ahead of the game.

It might do that, but it is quite long. Start with Bertrand Russell’s History of Western Philosophy. It is certainly Russell’s view and not in any way objective, but Coplestone’s in not objective either; it is Thomist in outlook. Alfred North Whitehead wrote, “The safest general characterization of the European philosophical tradition is that it consists of a series of footnotes to Plato.” That is an exaggeration, of course, but if there is anything in it, one might get a bird’s-eye view by giving a thorough reading to Plato’s Republic. In My view, the real bailiwick of philosophy is epistemology, and one might get a fairly complete view of that inquiry by reading Plato’s Theaetetus, Decartes’ Meditations on First Philosophy, Hume’s An Enquiry Concerning Human Understanding, Kant’s Critique of Pure Reason (big job), and, perhaps, Karl Popper’s Objective Knowledge.
